Palladium immobilized on the surface of MMT K 10 with the aid of [BMIM][BF4]: An efficient catalyst for Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions Preeti Rekha Boruah a Praveen Singh Gehlot b Arvind Kumar b Diganta Sarma a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Dibrugarh University, Dibrugarh, 786004, Assam, India Department of Chemistry Dibrugarh University Dibrugarh Assam 786004 India b Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR)‐Central Salt and Marine Chemicals Research Institute, Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), G. Graphical abstract The designing of a new heterogeneous catalyst for palladium catalyzed Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions at room temperature is of great interest from green chemistry perspectives. In this work, neutral ionic liquid [BMIM][BF4] was used as an anchor for immobilizing palladium on the surface of MMT K 10. The procedure for the synthesis of the catalyst is quite simple and the entire process is conducted under room temperature. The catalyst formed consists of palladium nanoparticles which were characterized by TEM, SEM and XRD. The new heterogeneous catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity toward biaryl synthesis in water at room temperature. Keywords Ionic liquids MMT K 10 Palladium Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling 1 Introduction In the recent days ionic liquids (ILs) have dragged the interest of the synthetic organic chemistry to a great extent. Since its discovery in the 20th century, ILs have found wide applications in a variety of synthetic, separation and electrochemical processes [1]. The unique properties of ILs such as wide range of solubility, low to very low volatility, not capable of burning with flames, good to very good thermal stability properties relative to other similar materials, non corrosive to metals, low vapor pressure, good conductivity, etc. make them superior over conventional organic solvents [2] Although the first ionic liquid Ethyl Ammonium Nitrate (EAN) prepared by Welden could not be used in any reaction because of its explosive nature, it paved the path for the synthesis of its homologues and many other derivatives. Ionic liquids can be designed to perform specific tasks by replacing any one of the ionic species in the salt and so are commonly known as ‘task specific ionic liquids’ (TSILs). TSILs have played many crucial roles in a number of synthetic reactions such as Knoevenagel reaction, Ficher Indole synthesis, Baeyer condensation, Pechmann reaction, Friedel-Crafts reactions, etc [3–5]. Among the various types of green solvents recognized by Green chemistry, ionic liquids are one of the most interesting alternative solvents and are now in trend [6,7]. Homogeneous catalysis in ILs ensures a good catalytic yield as well as great reusability of the catalytic system [8]. But such catalytic reactions in IL also involve certain disadvantages such as requirement of a good volume of the IL and sometimes reactions require ambient temperature for full conversion of the reactants to the desired product [9]. Heterogeneous catalysis, on the other hand, provides a very efficient and clean technique for organic synthesis which ensures a good catalytic yield and at the same time facilitates the reuse of the catalytic system for a number of times. Metal anchored on the surface of a solid support like silica gel, clay, zeolites, carbon nanotubes, etc. have become an area of extensive research. Noble metal nanoparticles play an important role in the area of heterogeneous catalysis. Designing a new class of heterogeneous catalyst by immobilizing an IL on the surface of a solid support seems to be an area of great interest [10]. Solid supported ionic liquids work with the principles of green chemistry by overcoming a number of disadvantages faced during a homogeneous reaction by ensuring an easy and good separation of products, good catalytic yield, low catalyst loading and reusability of the catalyst for a number of times. Moreover introducing certain functional groups into the structure of ILs also helps in the reaction rate by simply enhancing the rate of formation of the product or by introducing the desired condition for the reaction. ILs are polar species which facilitate the holding of a number of ionic species like transition metal complexes, ions, ligands, etc. This property of ionic liquid facilitates the preparation of supported ionic liquid phase catalyst (SPIL). SPILs are generally prepared by immobilizing a film of IL on a solid support such as silica, clay, zeolite, etc. and followed by dissolving a homogenous mixture of the catalyst over the ionic liquid layer [11]. The resulting catalyst is a free flow solid catalyst where the metal species are anchored on the surface of the solid support with the aid of an IL. Anchoring noble metals on the surface of a solid support with the aid of an ionic liquid has brought a paradigm shift in heterogeneous catalysis. Palladium is one of the mostly used noble metal which has a wide range of applications in various coupling reactions [12]. Therefore, generating new heterogeneous catalysts of palladium by immobilizing the metal on the surface of a solid support is definitely of great economic importance. 2 Experimental In this work we have reported the preparation of a new catalyst by immobilizing [BMIM][BF4] on the surface of montmorillonite clay MMT K 10 and this was followed by addition of Pd(OAc)2 solution into the IL- clay mixture at room temperature. The resulting is a free flow powder showing intrinsic properties of formation of palladium nanoparticles. Moreover the catalyst showed high selectivity and easy separation for Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction of aryl halides and arylboronic acids. 2.1 Synthesis of the catalyst 2.1.1 Synthesis of 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate [BMIM][BF4] 1-Methylimidazole (10 g, 121.803 mmol) was reacted with more than equimolar amount of n- butylbromide (25.036 g, 182.705 mmol) at 100 °C for about 10 h. After completion of the reaction the visibility of two layers of liquid were seen. The excess n- butylbromide was drained off and the remaining viscous layer thus obtained was [BMIM][Br]. The IL layer was washed 4–5 times with ethylacetate and then dried in the rotary evaporator under reduced pressure, which was further reacted with equimolar amount of NaBF4 (13.293 g, 121.083 mmol) in acetone for 24 h at room temperature to obtain the required ionic liquid [BMIM][BF4]. The ionic liquid thus obtained was filtered and acetone was dried off from the IL in the rotary evaporator under reduced pressure. 2.1.2 Immobilization of Pd(OAc)2 in [BMIM][BF4] with the aid of MMT K-10 0.5 g of MMT K10 was dispersed in a solution of [BMIM][BF4] and stirred for 5–6 h at room temperature. Thereafter, the clay immobilized IL was recovered by centrifugation. The same process was repeated for three times. A solution of 2.5 ml of Pd(OAc)2 (8 mg/ml water) was added to it and stirred for another 24 h (Fig. 1 ). The catalyst thus obtained was recovered by centrifugation followed by drying in hot air oven and it was named as Palladium immobilized Clay supported Ionic Liquid-1 (PCIL-1). By applying similar procedure, we also synthesized Kaolinite and Montmorillonite KSF supported PCILs and abbreviated as PCIL-2 and PCIL-3 respectively. Impregnation of the ionic liquid on the surface of MMT K 10 was evidenced by SEM EDX. 2.2 Characterization of the catalyst 2.2.1 TEM and SEM-EDX analysis The size and shape of the particles of the obtained catalyst were investigated using Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and TEM images (Fig. 2 ) of PCIL-1 reveals the formation of palladium nanoparticles with sizes varying from 2 to 5 nm and mostly spherical in shape. However, the DLS scattering (Fig. 3 ) shows that maximum of the NPs lie in the range of 35–40 nm. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) of the prepared catalyst powder was also performed which clearly shows the formation of palladium nanoflower (Fig. 4 ). EDX of PCIL-1 shows strong signals at carbon, nitrogen and palladium regions indicating the impregnation of the ionic liquid and palladium into the solid support. 2.2.2 XRD analysis The powder XRD of the catalyst was performed and strong signals corresponding to (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0) and (3 1 1) lattice planes indicate the formation of palladium nanoparticles (Fig. 5 ). 2.2.3 TGA and DTG The TGA and DTG analysis of catalyst PCIL-1 were done under nitrogen environment with a heating rate of 10 °C/min and it was observed that the catalyst has wide range of temperature tolerance which indicates that it could be used for high temperature reactions (Fig. 6 ). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic efficiency of PCIL-1 for Suzuki–Miyaura reactions of aryl halides with arylboronic acids In order to evaluate the catalytic activity of PCIL-1, we chose Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling reaction for our study. Synthetic organic chemistry always strives towards the development of novel green protocols for various synthetic transformation reactions. CC bond forming cross-coupling reactions comprise one of the most important class of synthetic reactions which are of great interest in the recent days. The palladium catalyzed Suzuki-Miyaura (SM) reaction is one of the most important and versatile methods for the construction of biaryl moieties by the reaction of an aryl halide or triflate with an organoborane. Biaryl moieties are important structures for a number of agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals and many industrially important compounds. The conventional SM reaction was carried out in the presence of a base in an organic solvent, catalyzed by a palladium complex of bulky phosphine groups. Since the discovery of this method, synthetic chemists are in a continuous run to develop mild and efficient methodologies by varying the parameters such as base, ligand, metal complexes etc. [13,14]. In the recent days ionic liquids have emerged as great synthetic tool for green chemistry. Ionic liquid assisted Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions have been successfully carried out by different research groups [15–20]. Heterogeneous catalyst based on ionic liquids has dragged the attention of the scientific community to a great extent. Suzuki et al. carried out the coupling of aryl halides and aryl boronic acids in ethanol using reusable solid supported IL catalyst (Pd-SILC) obtained by immobilizing Pd(OAc)2 in diethylaminopropylated (NDEAP) alumina pores with the aid of neutral [bmim]PF6 [21]. Shin et al. reported the successful coupling of aryl halides and aryl boronic acids in the presence of a IL based heterogeneous catalyst obtained by immobilizing Pd-NPs onto spherical silica particles using a molecular band composed of imidazolium chloride and urea cross-links [22]. Many such strategies were reported by Safavi, Yang, Clark, Karimi and their research groups [23–26]. In our study we have used our catalyst PCIL-1 for exploring the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction under very mild condition at room temperature under aerobic conditions, without the use of any ligands/additives/promoters/harmful organic solvent. Catalyst PCIL-1 was used as a palladium precursor for Suzuki-Miyaura reaction between phenylboronic acid and 4-iodoanisole (Scheme 1 ) in H2O/ iPrOH (1:1 v/v) in the presence of a base K2CO3 (Table 1 ). It was observed that at room temperature the reaction afforded an excellent yield of 98% (isolated yield) in 1 h reaction time without the formation of any homocoupling product of boronic acid with very little catalyst loading (0.5 mol %) (Table 1 , entry 2). The reaction proceeded well without the use of any external ligand/additive/promoter etc. and the separation of the product from the reaction mixture was also very easy. In order to check the activity of our catalyst in SM coupling reaction, we conducted another reaction between 4-iodoanisole and phenyl boronic acid in H2O/ iPrOH (1:1 v/v) mixture using K2CO3 base in the absence of catalyst. However, no product formation was observed even after 24 h of reaction time. This result clearly indicates that PCIL-1 catalyzes the former reaction very efficiently under a potential greener condition. The catalytic activity of the PCIL-1 system was investigated for various electron rich/ electron deficient arylboronic acids and aryl halides. It was found that under the optimized reaction condition the product yield was quite satisfactory for almost all reactions (Table 2 ). All the reactions were carried out at room temperature and under aerobic conditions. As seen in Table 2, all the reactions afforded excellent yields of their respective biaryl adducts irrespective of the presence of any electron donating or electron releasing functional group in the substrate, within a very short period of time and at room temperature without the formation of any byproduct. Heteroaryl halides interestingly gave similar results (Table 2, entries 16 & 17). Synthesis of biaryls from chloroaryls has been a very challenging task because of the low reactivity of aryl chlorides due to high bond dissociation energy of C-Cl bond which inhibits the oxidative addition step of the aryl chlorides in Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions. The efficiency of this catalyst in SM reaction for aryl chlorides with aryl boronic acid was tested and it was observed that aryl chlorides with either electron donating or electron withdrawing groups gave moderate yields of the desired coupling product with no formation of the unwanted homocoupling product of the boronic acids at room temperature which was quite noteworthy (Table 2, entries 18–22). 3.2 Reusability of the catalytic system One of the most interesting features of this catalytic system is recyclability and reusability of the catalytic system. The reusability of the catalyst PCIL-1 was investigated for SM cross coupling reaction of 4-iodoanisole with phenylboronic acid (Table 3 ). After the first reaction cycle, diethyl ethyl ether was added into the reaction mixture and this was followed by high centrifugation. The clear diethyl ether layer was separated and dried to obtain the desired crude product. The catalytic system was washed for several times until all the products get separated into the diethyl ether layer. Then, fresh reactants were added into the recovered catalytic system and interestingly, similar results were obtained up to the fifth cycle under the same optimized reaction conditions. These results clearly confirm that our catalytic system can be reused up to five times without any substantial loss in its catalytic activity (Table 3, entries 1–5). To know the exact composition of the catalyst after recycling, we performed the ICP analysis of the recycled catalyst (after 5th cycle) and we found 1.97% Pd whereas the ICP-OES of the original catalyst was found to be 2.11% Pd. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have presented a very green, efficient protocol for synthesis of palladium nanoparticles which gave excellent catalytic yields of Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions at room temperature in water. Although the phenomenon behind the formation of the palladium nanoparticles is not quite understood, it is believed that both electrostatic and coordination forces being very strong, results in the formation of a very stable catalyst palladium immobilized on the MMT K 10 with the aid of [BMIM][BF4]. The practical applications of the catalytic system are not completely explored. However, future work in this area is still under progress.
